item.title: Simple, yet efficient registration proccess (PHP)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Two glaring problems come right out at me.

First, strip_tags() doesn’t provide protection like mysql_real_escape_string() does, you should ALWAYS use that function before passing any variables to mysql.

Second:
// Add some encryption to our passwords
$password = md5($password);
$v_password = md5($v_password);
md5 is a hash, not encryption, they are two totally different things. Also, a simple md5 hash for a password is a horrible idea and easily bruteforced in seconds with rainbow tables, you should at least use sha1 and ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS use a salt.

<?php	
/*
#############################################
=============================================
Efficient Registration Checker and Proccessor
---------------------------------------------
Credits:-Me----------------------------------
=============================================
#############################################
*/		
	// Easier for editing - set to default
	$host = localhost; // Default
	$database = root; // Your databases name
	$database_user = root; // Your database password
	$database_password = admin; // Your database password
	
	// Connect to database && MySQL processing
	$connect =  mysql_connect("$host", "$database", "$database_password") or die(mysql_error());
	mysql_select_db("$database_user") or die(mysql_error());
	
	// If we connected successfully
	if ( $connect == true ) {
			
		// Retrieve the information we've submitted from the form
		#####We've stripped HTML and SCRIPT tags from all fields for security issues#####
		$submit = strip_tags($_POST['submit']); // Calling $submit to take place for $_POST['submit']
		$username = mysql_real_escape_string(strip_tags($_POST['username'])); // Calling $username to take place for $_POST['username']
		$password = mysql_real_escape_string(strip_tags($_POST['password'])); // Calling $password to take place for $_POST['password']
		$v_password = mysql_real_escape_string(strip_tags($_POST['v_password'])); // Password validation
		$email = mysql_real_escape_string(strip_tags($_POST['email'])); // Calling $email to take place for $_POST['email']
		$v_email = mysql_real_escape_string(strip_tags($_POST['v_email'])); // Email validation
		$date = date("m-d-Y"); // Example: 01-01-2010 - MM-DD-YYYY
		
		// Send the user a lovely message
		$errorMessage = "<center><strong>There was an error while trying to process your registration form, please recheck all the fields, and try again.</strong></center><p></p>";
		
		// If the user has pressed the submit button
		if ( $submit == true ) {
		
			// Select our table and the field name, in this case, it's the field username
			$c_user = mysql_query("SELECT username FROM users WHERE username='$username'");
			// We're giving $id_u equal to numrows function, which has its query as c_user, which we declared before this
			$id_u = mysql_num_rows($c_user);	
			
			// If there is an existing username matching the user's typed in username
			if ( $id_u != 0 ) {
			
				echo "<center>That username is taken.</center>";
			
			// If the username is not taken...
			} else {
			
				// Checks if no username OR password was entered, then it will select one or the other
				if ( ( !$username ) || ( !$password ) || ( !$v_password ) || ( !$email ) || ( !$v_email ) ) {
					
					// Display default error message
					echo $errorMessage;
					// If no username was entered
					if ( !$username ) {	
						echo "<center>Please enter a username.</center>";
					}
					// If no password was entered
					if ( !$password ) {				
						echo "<center>Please enter a password.</center>";
					}
					// If no confirmation password was entered
					if ( !$v_password ) {
						echo "<center>Please re-enter your password.</center>";
					}
					// If no email address was entered
					if ( !$email ) {
						echo "<center>Please enter your email address.</center>";
					}
					// If no confirmation email was entered
					if ( !$v_email ) {
						echo "<center>Please re-enter your email address.</center>";
					}
				// If everything succeeds so far... 
				} else {
					#####Now we're going to check for length issues#####
					
					// Will select any of the given statements in the code blocks - highly efficient method
					if ( strlen( $username ) >= 26 || strlen( $username ) <=2 || strlen( $password ) >= 26 || strlen( $password ) <= 2 || strlen( $email ) <= 4 || strlen( $email ) >=51 ) {
						
						// Display default error message
						echo $errorMessage;
						
						// If the entered username is greater than or equal to twenty-six characters (less than 25)
						if ( strlen( $username ) >= 26 ) {
							echo "<center>Username max limit is 25 characters!</center>";
						}
						
						// If the entered username is less than or equal to two characters (greater than 2)
						if ( strlen( $username ) <= 2 ) {
							echo "<center>Username must be at least 3 characters long!</center>";
						}
						
						// If the entered password is greater than or equal to twenty-six characters (less than 25)
						if ( strlen( $password ) >= 26 ) {
							echo "<center>Password max limit is 25 characters!</center>";
						}
						
						// If the entered password is less than or equal to two characters (greater than 2)
						if ( strlen( $password ) <= 2 ) {
							echo "<center>Password must be at least 3 characters long!</center>";
						}	
						// If the entered email is greater than or equal to twenty-six characters (less than 50)
						if ( strlen( $password ) >= 51 ) {
							echo "<center>Email address max limit is 50 characters!</center>";
						}
						
						// If the entered email is less than or equal to two characters (greater than 5)
						if ( strlen( $email ) <= 4 ) {
							echo "<center>Email address must be at least 5 characters long!</center>";
						}
					} else {
						#####Now we're going to check for matching variable characters for passwords and email addresses#####
						
						// Extremely stable statements
						if ( $password != $v_password || $v_password != $password || $email != $v_email || $v_email != $email  ) {
							echo $errorMessage;
							
							// If the user's password is not equal to the confirmation form for the user's password, or the other way around
							if ( $password != $v_password || $v_password != $password ) {
								echo "<center>Your passwords do not match.</center>";
							}
							
							// If the user's email is not equal to the confirmation form for the user's email, or the other way around
							if ( $email != $v_email || $v_email != $email ) {
								echo "<center>Your email addresses do not match.</center>";
							}
						// If everything succeeds so far... 
						} else {
							#####Let's finally insert some data!#####
							
							// Hash
							$salt = "aE4sk85HslOp19ko1J8k3MN1m";
		                                        $password = sha1($salt.$password);
                                                        $v_password = sha1($salt.$v_password);
							
							// You might have to take out some of those, because my table includes a bit more than yours might
							$query = mysql_query("INSERT INTO users VALUES ('', '$username', '$password', '$email', '$date', '0', '');");
							echo "<center>Success!</center>";
						}
					}
				}
			}
		}
		
		// Display our form
		echo "
			<center>
				<form action='register.php' method='post'>
					<strong>Username: </strong><input type='text' name='username' /><br /><br />
					<strong>Password: </strong><input type='password' name='password' /><br />
					<strong>Confirm Password: </strong><input type='password' name='v_password' /><br /><br />
					<strong>Email Address: </strong><input type=text' name='email' /><br />
					<strong>Confirm Email Address: </strong><input type=text' name='v_email' /><br /><br />
					<input type='submit' name='submit' value='Submit' />
				</form>
			</center>	
		";
	
	} else {
		echo "<center>There was a problem connecting.</center>";
	}
?>

Ass
I’ve written up a registration process (which I use for my website), that is simple, yet efficient.

What it does, and what it checks for - it may do more…

[ul][li]Checks if the user name is taken or not in the database[/li]
[li]Checks if all fields were entered[/li]
[li]Proper submission and connection checks[/li]
[li]Checks for length of the strings[/li]
[li]Includes email, password, date and user name[/li]
[li]Checks for matching verification for passwords and user names[/li]
[li]Gives the password a sha1 salt hash[/li][/ul]

I made a table and used these fields:

    ID - Primary - Auto Increment
    Username - Varchar - 25(L)
    Password - Varchar - 25(L)
    Email - Varchar - 50(L)
    Date - Date

Edit:
If you use it, don’t forget to delete the two extra inserted fields when it takes the data from the form and adds it to the database table.

This:

$query = mysql_query("INSERT INTO users VALUES ('', '$username', '$password', '$email', '$date', '0', '');");

Just make it

$query = mysql_query("INSERT INTO users VALUES ('', '$username', '$password', '$email', '$date');");
